title: How did philosophy begin in ancient Greece? - Quora

response.answer_text: Historically speaking, Western Philosophy generally traces its origins to Thales of Miletus, a Greek living in Asia Minor in the 7th c. BCE. Thales studied all sorts of subjects, from astronomy to mathematics to agriculture and meteorology, and was well known in his home town for being very bright and curious. But he didn’t seem concerned with anything practical. Supposedly he was once teased by an Aristocrat for being poor, which the Aristocrat suggested meant he didn’t know anything, or at least that everything he knew was useless. So Thales did what any good philosopher does when someone teases him about having studied useless things: he went into business. He realized there would a huge olive harvest one year and promptly bought up all the olive presses. Sure enough, the olive crop was bountiful, and suddenly he was able to charge whatever he wanted for people to use the presses. He made a fortune, but it was all just to prove a point: that he knew things, and that they could be useful, but that his concern wasn’t with riches or power. He just wanted to be wise and know stuff, for its own sake, regardless of practical concerns. A second story picks up on this point: one day he’s just wandering around, looking at the sky, pondering the nature of reality, and falls into a well because he’s not looking where he’s going. A passing slave girl has to help him get out. Once he’s been saved she promptly teases him about knowing everything about the heavens, but nothing about what’s under his feet. What this story makes clear is something the other might obscure: for Thales, and those that would follow him, theoretical knowledge can be useful, practically speaking, but it’s valuable in itself even if pursuing it can be practically detrimental. And it’s this idea that allows the Greeks to give birth to a rich philosophical tradition without being great engineers or having a burgeoning civilization like the Babylonians and Egyptians. Like Thales, the Greek philosophers valued learning and wonder even when it didn’t have an immediate practical purpose. Thales is also well known for his claim that “Everything is really water,” and this makes the point clear, for it’s hard to imagine a practical application to the claim that all things are made of water! And as wild as it may sound, it makes some sense if you think about it: you plant a seed and it grows when you water it; you deprive a man of water and he dies. But whether this idea makes perfect sense or not, it also makes clear that Thales things were not exactly as they appear (really it’s all water) and that if we thought carefully enough about it we could eventually come to understand things as they really are. So Thales gives us the first instance the distinction between appearance and reality, the basis of the phrase “things are not always what they seem.” Thales was the first person to take that kind of leap, and while the Egyptians, Bablyonians, and other peoples at the time didn’t seem to be pursuing those kinds of questions, those Greeks that followed Thales thought deeply about the hidden causes behind the appearances of things; but importantly, they wanted to know these things just because they were curious, not because they thought it would be useful in any way. So the pursuit of knowledge and wisdom for their own sake, really, is the start of philosophy. Aristotle himself (who is often referred to simply as “The Philosopher”) says as much, identifying Thales’s concern with understanding the reality behind the appearances as the starting point of all philosophical thinking.

Thales of Miletus is widely considered the first "western" philosopher. He lived in the 7th century in Asia Minor, in one of the Greek city-states that bordered Persia known collectively as Ionia, and was the first person that we know of in any civilization, eastern or western, to say that natural phenomena were caused by, well, natural forces, rather than by the gods. Before Thales, somebody might say that an earthquake was caused by Poseidon's anger. Thales suggested that Poseidon in his anger shook the water that the earth floated in, thereby disturbing the earth's equilibrium, which then caused an earthquake. So in some ways he was much more the first scientist than the first philosopher. But he was essentially the first person to say, well, what if we've been wrong all along about X? He established what's called the Ionian School of philosophy, which was continued by his student Anaximander and by his student Anaximenes, and so on and so on. Eventually this way of doing things came to Athens, where Socrates picked it up a couple of centuries later. (Note that Confucius and the Buddha lived around the same time as Socrates, and so are also post-Ionian School. There are of course other eastern philosophers from before that time, but I'd be out of my depth trying to discuss them.)

One way to see it is that it began with myths, which expressed the principles of philosophy in ways that were understood at a subconscious level. Gradually these ‘interior truths’ were articulated explicitly and integrated with the rational mind. The myths sprung forth from the human collective conscious: Nature itself wishes human beings to become philosophers.
